title: Rybachy Peninsula
text:
Rybachy Peninsula (, "poluostrov Rybachiy"; ; ; ) is the northernmost part of continental <a href="European%20Russia">European Russia</a>. Its name is translated as "Fisher Peninsula". It is connected with the <a href="Sredny%20Peninsula">Sredny Peninsula</a>, "Middle Peninsula" by a thin <a href="isthmus">isthmus</a>. So the peninsula is in fact nearly completely surrounded by water. Administratively, it is included into <a href="Pechengsky%20District">Pechengsky District</a> of <a href="Murmansk%20Oblast">Murmansk Oblast</a> and is within several hours of ride from <a href="Murmansk">Murmansk</a>.
Main occupations of the population are <a href="reindeer">reindeer</a> <a href="herding">herding</a> and (since 2003) <a href="petroleum">petroleum</a> drilling.
History.
The peninsula lies in an area where borders were marked relatively late; the Norwegian-Russian border was drawn in 1826, leaving Rybachy on the Russian side of the border. At the time, several Norwegian settlers lived on the peninsula.
After the <a href="Russian%20Revolution%20%281917%29">Russian Revolution</a>, the western parts of Sredny and Rybachy were ceded to Finland. After the <a href="Winter%20War">Winter War</a> of 1939–1940, Finland ceded them to the Soviet Union by the <a href="Moscow%20Peace%20Treaty">Moscow Peace Treaty</a>. The Norwegian settlers became "trapped" in Soviet Russia after the revolution; some of their descendants were allowed Norwegian citizenship after <a href="revolutions%20of%201989">the fall of the Iron Curtain</a>.
During the <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> for three years it was an arena of a positional war between Germans and Soviets. The peninsula covered the access to Murmansk and <a href="Arkhangelsk">Arkhangelsk</a>, which were the main gates for the <a href="Lend-Lease">Lend-Lease</a>. The front split the peninsula in two parts, both sides having heavily fortified positions.
Before the <a href="dissolution%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> the territory was heavily militarized because of the immediate vicinity of <a href="Norway">Norway</a>, a <a href="NATO">NATO</a> member. Now the military is removed, but in 2005 the territory was still closed to foreigners.
